online.game
Interface BoardProtocol

All Known Implementing Classes:
GoBoard
public interface BoardProtocol

this is the visible contract between "board" objects and the general parts of the game system. Anything not in this protocol is really a private matter between your board class and your viewer and robot classes.

Author:
ddyer

Method Detail

DoneState

boolean DoneState()
return true if the board should allow a "done" action. This is used internally as a matter of convention, but externally it's used to trigger "tick tick" sounds to remind the user he's still expected to act.

Execute

boolean Execute(commonMove m,
                replayMode mode)
execute a move. This should be the only way the internals of board objects are modified by the viewer class. Boards may do reasonable consistency checking, and should call G.Error(java.lang.String, java.lang.Object...) if something is wrong with the move. By convention, the robot should only attempt legal moves, and the viewer should only allow legal moves to be made.

Parameters:
m - a commonMove
Returns:
true if the move was successfully executed.

Digest

long Digest()
return a 32 Bit digest of the board state. Any significant board state change should result in a different digest.

A cloned board should result in the same digest. Reinitializing and replaying a series of moves should result in the same digest. A duplicate endgame position should result in the same digest. When a robot makes a trial move, and unmakes it, the same digest should result, and so on.

Digests are also used in real time to detect repeated positions, to detect "follower fraud" and over long periods of time to detect deliberately replaying the same game to inflate rankings.

Returns:
an integer

SetDrawState

void SetDrawState()
called when a three-times-repeated position is detected. Depending on the game, this may indicate a draw, or it may indicate a bug in the bookkeeping.

Unexpected calls to this method frequently indicate that a viewer's commonCanvas.EditHistory(online.game.commonMove) has not edited out repeated do-undo sequences by an indecisive player.

GameOver

boolean GameOver()
return true if the game is at an end-of-game state. Normally, this is implemented as game_state==GAMEOVER_STATE. This is used to trigger a phase transition from honest play to after-game review.

Returns:
true if the game is at an end

WinForPlayer

boolean WinForPlayer(int idx)
return true if the player identified by idx has won the game. This is used when scoring 2 player games. It's an error for there to be more than one winner, but it's ok if there is no winner.

Parameters:
idx -
Returns:
true if the player has won

moveNumber

int moveNumber()
return the current move number. Changes in move numbers are used to trigger new columns in the visible game log.

Returns:
the current move number

whoseTurn

int whoseTurn()
return the index of the current player. This index doesn't necessarily correspond to the position of commonPlayer objects or the seat position. It's purely an internal board variable that the board will change from time to time.

Returns:
an integer representing the current player

sameboard

void sameboard(BoardProtocol other)
compare two boards and throw an error if they are not the same. This is used to verify copies of the board for the robot, and also to verify that replaying the current move history results in the same board position.

setWhoseTurn

void setWhoseTurn(int pn)
this is used when initializing games to set the starting player or the next player. It's sometimes convenient to breakpoint this method.

Parameters:
pn -

DigestState

boolean DigestState()
return true if the board's internal state should be digested and saved to detect repetitions.

Returns:
true if this board state should be digested

encodeCellPosition

java.awt.Point encodeCellPosition(int x,
                                  int y,
                                  double cellsize)
encode the position of some point on the board in a board-specific way. Typically this becomes the closest cell. The purpose of this encoding is so the visible mouse position will hover near the same object, even if the viewer is using a different view of the board.

Parameters:
x -
y -
cellsize -
Returns:
a Point
See Also:
decodeCellPosition(int, int, double)

decodeCellPosition

java.awt.Point decodeCellPosition(int x,
                                  int y,
                                  double cellsize)
reverse the encoding done by encodeCellPosition

Parameters:
x -
y -
cellsize -
Returns:
a Point
See Also:
encodeCellPosition(int, int, double)

cellSize

int cellSize()
Returns:
the approximate size, in pixels, of a board square.

movingObjectIndex

int movingObjectIndex()
get an index that encodes the object that has been picked up and is tracking with the mouse. This is use to tell the clients which object to depict.

Returns:
an index representing the currently moving object.

cloneBoard

BoardProtocol cloneBoard()
create a copy of the current board. This is used to initialize the board used by the robot, and also to verify the integrity and reproducibility of the game record.

Returns:
a new board

copyFrom

void copyFrom(BoardProtocol from)
make this board a copy of "from", which is another board of the current real type.

Parameters:
from -

doInit

void doInit()
re-initialize the board back to the state before any moves were made. Any generic setup or state, such as the number of players or the random seed for the game should be preserved.

nPlayers

int nPlayers()
Returns:
the number of players in the current game

setPermissiveReplay

void setPermissiveReplay(boolean f)
allow illegal moves (permissive replay)
